user.biography: History isn't made by kings or politicians, it is made by us: billions of ordinary people ✊ podcast | social | patreon | store

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 23, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
On this day, 24 August 1943, French philosopher and anti-fascist Simone Weil died in London. Previously she had opposed French colonialism in Asia and North Africa, taken part in the factory occupations during the popular front government in 1936, then travelled to Spain to fight against the right-wing military rising of general Francisco Franco. Weil fought in the Durruti column until she was injured in an accident and left the country. In collaborationist Vichy France, she got a job as an agricultural labourer and worked with the resistance, until she travelled to London with her Jewish parents to keep them safe. There she continued writing on behalf of the resistance, sleeping only around three hours per night. Her cause of death was officially designated a suicide from self-starvation and tuberculosis, but biographers state that while people in occupied France lived on minimal food rations, Weil did the same, which severely worsened her illness.
Learn more about the Spanish civil war in our podcast episodes 39-40: https://workingclasshistory.com/2020/06/17/e39-the-spanish-civil-war-an-introduction/
Pictured: Weil in Spain

On this day, 23 August 1924, French resistance fighter Madeleine Riffaud was born. On her 20th birthday, 23 August 1944, she engaged in her most successful resistance action. Along with three other fighters and a train driver, Riffaud successfully captured a Nazi supply train complete with 80 soldiers on board. Her unit threw all the grenades and explosives they had at the train, then used fireworks to make the Germans believe they were outnumbered and outgunned. 
Riffaud recalled to Agence France-Presse in an interview: “We made an incredible amount of noise and it terrified the poor Germans and they pulled back into a tunnel. The locomotive was still sticking out and we managed to persuade a retired train driver who was washing the dishes with his wife to go down with us to detach it. He was a brave man. We warned him that he would be a perfect target, but he told us not to worry, and crawled underneath the engine, unhooked it and drove it away, and then walked home. We didn’t even think to thank him.”
The resistance activists were then backed up by some firefighters and the local mayor, until eventually the Germans, stranded in the tunnel, surrendered. At that point Riffaud realised it was her birthday, and they then celebrated with dried sausages, jam and ham seized from the train.
Pictured: Riffaud in 1968
This action is one of hundreds of stories in our archive we have mapped the exact location it took place. We need your help to bring our history map and timelines to life, to be publicly available for all, so if you can please consider making a small donation to help us develop a free web app: https://www.gofundme.com/f/help-us-build-a-web-app
To access this hyperlink, click our link in bio, swipe left then click this photo

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 23, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
On this day, 23 August 1966, 200 Aboriginal workers at the Wave Hill pastoral station in Australia walked out on strike for equal pay with white workers. They remained out for nine years, and from a wage dispute they then demanded return of the land to them, from British aristocrat Lord Vestey. They were eventually successful in being given back a proportion of the land. 
This is a short history of the dispute: https://libcom.org/history/wave-hill-walk-1966-1975

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 22, 2021. May be an illustration.

node.text:
On this day, 23 August 1851, a violent riot broke out in Sydney, Australia when police tried to arrest Michael Knight, a sailor who was wearing women's clothing. A police constable had arrived on the scene to quell the supposed "disorder" and intercepted Michael at a pub. To the cheers of the other patrons, Knight decked the officer and fled. While the officer called for reinforcements, Knight proceeded to St Philip's church and began abusing the parishioners until subdued, arrested and dragged to a watch-house by seven police officers. On hearing of the arrest, sailors from two military ships gathered a crowd who then marched on several watch-houses, attacking police and succeeding in freeing many prisoners, although not Knight, who was later fined. 
We have produced a poster commemorating this event, illustrated by Agustin Huarte, to help fund our work: https://shop.workingclasshistory.com/collections/homeware/products/sydney-sailors-riot-poster
To access this hyperlink, click our link in bio, swipe left then click this photo

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 22, 2021. May be a black-and-white image of 1 person.

node.text:
On this day, 22 August 1893, Dorothy Parker, Jewish US poet, writer, activist, two-time Academy Award nominee and victim of Hollywood blacklisting, was born. 
She became radicalised in 1927 with the executions of Italian anarchists Sacco and Vanzetti, in support of whom she was demonstrating when she was first arrested. Parker travelled to Spain during the civil war, and recounted in New Masses magazine: "when a[n air] raid comes in the daytime, you see little children wild with terror. They don’t cry. Only you see their eyes. I can still see those eyes. After one raid, I saw a great pile of rubble, and on the top of it a broken doll and a dead kitten—ruthless enemies to the fascists." 
Parker later helped found the Hollywood Anti-Nazi League, and helped rescue Spanish civil war veterans, children and orphans after the victory of right-wing general Francisco Franco. 
Called in front of the House Un-American Activities Committee, Parker warned: “For heaven’s sake, children, Fascism isn’t coming—it’s here. It’s dreadful. Stop it.”
FBI agents were sent to her house by J Edgar Hoover after she helped raise money to buy milk for Spanish children, and Parker was then blacklisted from working in Hollywood for much of her working life. 
This is a short history of the Hollywood blacklist: https://libcom.org/history/hollywood-blacklist-dan-georgakas

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 22, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, animal and text that says 'Ruben RubenCollio Collio'.

node.text:
On this day, 22 August 2016, Mapuche Indigenous environmental activist Macarena Valdés was found dead, hanging from the ceiling at her home in rural Chile by her 11-year-old son. Police ruled her death a suicide, but renowned forensic pathologist Luis Ravanal ruled that she was already dead by the time her body was hanged – a finding which was supported by British pathologist John Clark in a later report. 
Valdés and her husband, Rubén Collio, were campaigners against construction of a hydroelectric power plant by Austrian company RP Global. The plant had been given approval despite its failure to consult local Indigenous communities which is required by law. Local Indigenous people including Valdés and Collio had been intermittently protesting and blockading works since January. 
The day before Valdés' death, two officials from companies partnered with RP Global, visited her landlord demanding she expel Collio, and stating "there were many people who wanted to harm him." The pathologist submitted his report to the district attorney's office, but they decided to close the case. 
The power plant was subsequently completed, and on the second anniversary of Valdés' death, protesters from all across Chile gathered to demonstrate and commemorate her. Her family have also continued to campaign for justice, and in 2018 they found a police report that showing that a man's DNA was found on the rope. Prosecutors were then forced to reopen the case.

On this day, 22 August 1894, Willem Arondeus, gay Dutch resistance fighter, was born. Arondeus was later executed by the Nazis for his part in an attack on the Amsterdam public records office, which destroyed documents which will enable the Nazis to identify forgeries issued by the resistance. Before his death he asked a friend to later testify: "Let it be known that homosexuals are not cowards." 
Pictured: Arondeus, facing the camera

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 21, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and standing.

node.text:
On this day, 21 August 1791 the Haitian revolution began as 100,000 enslaved people rose up and eventually overthrew both slavery and French colonial rule, creating the world’s first Black republic. The revolutionary army also defeated Spanish colonial forces in what is now the Dominican Republic, as well as the British army which came to the aid of the colonialists. 
This book by CLR James is a detailed history of the revolution: https://libcom.org/library/black-jacobins-toussaint-louverture-san-domingo-revolution
Pictured: a painting of a battle during the revolution, by Auguste Raffet

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 20, 2021. May be an image of 9 people and people standing.

node.text: On this day, 21 August 1981, 140 mostly women workers at the Lee Jeans factory in Greenock, Scotland returned to work after winning a seven-month occupation of the plant against closure, having won their jobs back.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 20, 2021.

node.text:
Posting historical stories on social media is great, but it means that big corporations ultimately control the platforms. Behind the scenes we are working with the Yalla web development cooperative, based in the UK and Gaza, to build a powerful, interactive website containing timelines, maps and sources on all our thousands of stories. We need your help to make it a reality, so if you can, please consider donating here, or share this appeal: https://www.gofundme.com/f/help-us-build-a-web-app
To access this hyperlink, click our link in bio, swipe left then click this photo
Pictured is a beta version of the map feature

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 20, 2021. May be a black-and-white image of 5 people, people standing and text.

node.text:
On this day, 20 August 1976, the Grunwick strike began in London when Devshi Bhudia was dismissed from a photo processing plant for working too slowly and three colleagues walked out in his support. 
Three days later they began picketing in what became an iconic dispute and one of the key struggles of the working class, particularly the Asian and female working class in the UK in the late 20th century. 
One of the strikers, Jayaben Desai, told her manager before walking out: "What you are running is not a factory, it is a zoo. But in a zoo there are many types of animals. Some are monkeys who dance on your fingertips. Others are lions who can bite your head off. We are those lions, Mr Manager."
The workers remained out for nearly two years, and while they were unsuccessful in achieving their stated aims, they helped transform the UK workers' movement by pushing white union workers to recognise Asian, Black and migrant workers as their fellow workers rather than as rivals for jobs.
Learn the history of the strike in our first ever podcast episode (apologies the audio quality isn't great but we were still learning): https://workingclasshistory.com/2018/02/28/episode-1-the-grunwick-strike-1976/

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 19, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, child, standing, outdoors and text.

node.text: On this day, 20 August 2018, the first day of the school year, 15-year-old autistic school student Greta Thunberg began a solo school strike demanding government action on climate change. Instead of going to class, she printed leaflets declaring "We kids most often don’t do what you tell us to do. We do as you do. And since you grown-ups don’t give a shit about my future, I won’t either. My name is Greta and I’m in ninth grade. And I refuse school for the climate until the Swedish general election." Then she headed to the Swedish parliament building where she protested alone. Within a couple of days a handful of people began to join her, and she gave numerous interviews to journalists, making headlines around the world. Within a few months, hundreds of thousands of schoolchildren in hundreds of towns and cities around the world organised their own walkouts. While Thunberg as inspired many young people, some commentators have pointed out that she received much more favourable media coverage than Indigenous youth who have been using direct action and fighting police to protect biodiversity and fight climate change for years in places like Standing Rock in the United States.
